channel.title: BP to pay $33m a day
channel.description:
[center][url=http://i.telegraph.co.uk/telegraph/multimedia/archive/01635/oil-spill_1635761c.jpg][size=20pt]Oil spill image from space[/size][/url][/center]
"The company has been spending millions of dollars in an attempt to stop 5,000 barrels a day gushing into the ocean. Deepwater Horizon, the rig owned and operated by contractor Transocean, sank three weeks ago with the loss of 11 lives. Since then, the cost of BP's clean-up operation has soared from $350m (£238m) to $450m in just three days.", "Analysts at Barclays Capital estimate the maximum total cost of the clean-up, plus compensation, legal bills and lost revenue could be $22.6bn." - [url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/oilandgas/7721076/BP-oil-spill-clean-up-costs-spiral-to-33m-a-day.html]source[/url]

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Hey, BP knew they didn’t have the right tools. Hence the reason they contracted out Transocean to do the drilling.

Read full topic

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:16, topic:340030”]I still think it is unfair for BP to be left alone to fix everything up themselves. The rig is “owned and operated” by Transocean so shouldn’t they take full responsibility if anything bad like this happens? I’m surprised that enviro-fag companies aren’t providing money to clean up the oil because I would suspect that they do care that a lot of wildlife is being killed by the oil gushing into their habitats.

You guys are forgetting that petrol is not the only thing that crude oil is used for. Many other industries are being affected by this like plastic manufacturing etc etc.[/quote]

I think what matters now is cleaning that shit up, and start discussing about who is to blame later.

Read full topic

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:16, topic:340030”]I still think it is unfair for BP to be left alone to fix everything up themselves. The rig is “owned and operated” by Transocean so shouldn’t they take full responsibility if anything bad like this happens? I’m surprised that enviro-fag companies aren’t providing money to clean up the oil because I would suspect that they do care that a lot of wildlife is being killed by the oil gushing into their habitats.

You guys are forgetting that petrol is not the only thing that crude oil is used for. Many other industries are being affected by this like plastic manufacturing etc etc.[/quote]
And you are forgetting that BP isn’t the only oil giant.

Read full topic

I still think it is unfair for BP to be left alone to fix everything up themselves. The rig is “owned and operated” by Transocean so shouldn’t they take full responsibility if anything bad like this happens? I’m surprised that enviro-fag companies aren’t providing money to clean up the oil because I would suspect that they do care that a lot of wildlife is being killed by the oil gushing into their habitats.

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

xx matty xx:

there is a limit to how much weight a rocket can effectively take off with, and nuclear waste is very dense. even if they did manage to design massive rockets to dispose of large amounts of waste, it’d still be expensive and dangerous. they could irradiate half the population of the earth if something went wrong.

Optimum > Minimum

I do agree with you about your last sentence but to repeat myself, there are other ways to dispose nuclear waste. It would only happen if, as mentioned by you, the need for fossil fuels is totally gotten rid of which won’t happen that soon.

Read full topic

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

there is a limit to how much weight a rocket can effectively take off with, and nuclear waste is very dense. even if they did manage to design massive rockets to dispose of large amounts of waste, it’d still be expensive and dangerous. they could irradiate half the population of the earth if something went wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:12, topic:340030”]no, i meant that solar energy is useless because the startup and maintenance costs are not worth the return in energy. if we are in the mood for wasting money, we might as well put it into something more low risk than blasting nuclear waste into the air.

i know that there are other ways of disposing nuclear waste, but you mentioned space as though it was the best method.

and i don’t know what you mean by no one wanting small amounts of waste in a rocket…[/quote]
Oops, I edited my post before I saw your reply. This: “Right, building massive solar panels means huge maintenance. Maintenance isn’t simple (How Do The Do It? gives an idea) - they have to detect the nonworking panel, replace it manually without possibly damage any other panels under the hot sun.”

You mentioned about sending up rockets with relatively small amounts of waste - why would actually anyone send off rockets with minimum waste?

Read full topic

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

no, i meant that solar energy is useless because the startup and maintenance costs are not worth the return in energy. if we are in the mood for wasting money, we might as well put it into something more low risk than blasting nuclear waste into the air.

i know that there are other ways of disposing nuclear waste, but you mentioned space as though it was the best method.

and i don’t know what you mean by no one wanting small amounts of waste in a rocket…

Read full topic

item.title: BP to pay $33m a day
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:10, topic:340030”][quote author=Rixxx link=topic=436405.msg3206948#msg3206948 date=1273889709]

That probably wont do the economy any good.

Petrol rises no doubt too, they love to exploit stuff like this for an extra few pence.

Yes it has risen.

[quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=436405.msg3206621#msg3206621 date=1273874490]

Whoopee. Just another reason for us to move on to electric cars.
[/quote]even still, that electricity has to be generated somewhere. and i read once that when the chemicals for the batteries are made, this produces loads of toxic waste.

even if we get rid of the need for fossil fuels in power plants and switch to nuclear, there’s still radioactive waste. fusion research is wasting more power than it’s worth, and wind + solar are too shit atm to be of any use.

Out of earth is a good place for radioactive waste.
[/quote]and suppose something went wrong? we could get rained on by plutonium. and it would cost a fortune to keep sending up rockets with relatively small amounts of waste. we might as well just waste that money on building massive solar panels in the desert.[/quote]
Right, building massive solar panels means huge maintenance. Maintenance isn’t simple (How Do The Do It? gives an idea) - they have to detect the nonworking panel, replace it manually without possibly damage any other panels under the hot sun.

Surely no one would want small amounts of waste in a rocket. Alternatively, there are other ways to dispose nuclear waste.

Read full topic

Out of earth is a good place for radioactive waste.[/quote]and suppose something went wrong? we could get rained on by plutonium. and it would cost a fortune to keep sending up rockets with relatively small amounts of waste. we might as well just waste that money on building massive solar panels in the desert.
